Award.AbstractNarration:
The main goal of this project is to discover mathematical results that explain the formation and propagation of randomness in several models of fundamental importance in the physical sciences. The most familiar example of such phenomena is turbulence in three-dimensional flows. The project also includes the study of nonlinear waves in one dimension and the propagation of randomness by basic numerical algorithms. These examples are more tractable than fully developed turbulence, and are also of intrinsic interest. The theoretical results developed in this project assist the development of numerical methods for uncertainty quantification.

Three projects are considered: (a) a study of exactly solvable models in one-dimension including scalar conservation laws and integrable partial differential equations; (b) run time statistics for widely used iterative eigenvalue algorithms; and (c) random fluid flows modeling isotropic homogeneous turbulence in incompressible fluids. The purpose of projects (a) and (b) is to use the methods of integrable systems and probability theory to describe new classes of exactly solvable stochastic models. The purpose of project (c) is to develop solutions to the Euler equations of incompressible flow that describe fully developed turbulence, in consonance with experimentally observed scaling laws.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was primarily used to study a wide range of phenomena in the natural world. These include models for dielectric breakdown and lightning (branched conformal structures); soap bubble and grain boundary networks in materials science; the formation of closed shell nanostructures and synthetic self-assembly; and the study of strong discontinuities (shocks) in models of wave propagation. All these models share common mathematical features -- in particular, a common theme is the need to model such systems through a combination of tools from differential equations and probability theory. The support from this award was used to develop these tools in combination with the development of models for the phenomena under study.

This award was also used to study the reliability of fundamental numerical algorithms that form part of the infrastructure of modern computing. These algorithms share common themes with other aspects of the PI's work; in particular they may be modeled as random dynamical systems. This has allowed us to establish rigorous error bounds on the performance of these algorithms.

In our view the most significant scientific finding during the period of this award is a new description of branched conformal structures, termed the Dyson superprocess, that was developed in Vivian Olsiewski Healey's thesis and further work by the PI. This model provides the first continuum description for rather poorly understood branching phenomena corresponding to beautiful natural phenomena such as lightning.    

In addition to creating new science, this award was also used to support the development of young mathematicians. Three graduate students were trained by the PI during the period of this award. In addition, the PI also worked with three postdocs during this period.
